data.text: Contents
Introduction

Bed rails are commonly used in acute hospitals to reduce the risk of patients falling from the bed and injuring themselves. Bed rails may be useful in preventing slips, slides or rolls from the bed but are not without their potential risks. Careful assessment and monitoring is required to mitigate potential adverse events; the most serious of these being injury or death from asphyxiation following entrapment of the head, neck or chest. It is important to use bed rails in the right way, with the right person and using right equipment.

In addition, if used continuously or in conjunction with other significantly limiting practices, bed rails may be considered a Restrictive Intervention and reference should be made to the Restrictive Interventions policy.
Scope
This policy applies to adult patients cared for by Mid and South Essex Trust (‘the Trust') at risk of slipping, sliding or rolling from the bed or trolley
This policy does NOT apply to:
Paediatric wards; the needs of babies and children, the equipment used and the decision making process may be very different

People who are being advised by healthcare professionals on the use of bed rails in the home or care home environment. In these instances there may be a great deal of variables to consider in each individual case including informal careers, differing bed designs and environment considerations
Definitions

table_items.text: Padded covers which protect those vulnerable to skin tears or bruises if making direct contact with the rails
Bed rails/Safety Rails (previously referred to as “cot-sides”)

Rails that can be erected along the sides of a bed to provide a barrier to slipping, sliding or rolling from the bed to the floor. Bed rails may be Integral (incorporated into the bed design and supplied with or as an optional accessary by the bed manufacturer) or Third Party rails (removable rails not specific to any particular model of bed)
Rails which do not run continuously along the bed edge but which have a gap, usually to facilitate movement of a profiling bed

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Nursing staff:

Have the responsibility for reaching decisions regarding the use of bed rails and bumpers and reviewing regularly as required. They are responsible for communicating the reasons behind the decisions made with the patient and/next of kin and accurately documenting decisions and discussions in the clinical record in accordance with local policy and procedure
Health Care Support Workers:
Are responsible for being aware of the bed rail use of the patients under their care and ensuring that the rails are used as per assessment
Portering staff:
Are responsible for using bed rails for the transport of patients throughout the hospital and to ensure that when patients are returned to the ward the bed rails are left as assessed
MEMS staff:
Ensuring that bed rails are safely maintained and fit for purpose
All staff working within clinical areas:
Need to be aware of the purpose of bed rails and their associated risks so that any concerns may be raised appropriately
The use of rails on trolleys

In areas of the hospital which use trolleys rather than beds, rails should be used as the default position. Trolleys may present a greater risk of falls as they are narrower, higher than a standard bed height and usually used in the acute phase of the patients admission.

If a patient is confused, agitated and trying to climb from a trolley then intervention must be put in place to mitigate the risk, for example close supervision or transfer of the patient to a standard bed or chair.
The use of bed rails when transporting a patient around the hospital on a bed/trolley:

5.3.1  When transporting a patient around the hospital, between bays, wards or departments, bed rails should be raised as there is a greater risk of the patient slipping, sliding or rolling from the bed when in motion. The bed rails should be returned to their previous position (as assessed) when the patient is brought back to their bed space.
The use of bed rails in the ward setting:
Frequency of assessment/review:
On admission
On each significant change in the patient's condition
If the bed, mattress or other bed accessories are altered
At minimum of 7 days following the last previous assessment
Decision making:

5.6.1 Decisions regarding the use of bed rails should, wherever possible, be discussed with the patient or next of kin. The discussion must include the relative risks/benefits of their use and the reasoning for the decision. This discussion must be recorded in the medical record. The “Best Interest” process should be followed (see Policy for MCA/DoLs or equivalent).

5.6.2 Risk assessment must be individualised as there a number of variable factors which require consideration in each instance. The decision will be a considered balance of risk to benefit and circumstances may change rapidly requiring frequent monitoring.
Points to consider when undertaking the risk assessment include:
How likely is it that the patient may slip, slide or roll from the bed?
Do they use bed rails in their normal place of residence?
Could the use of bed rails increase the risks to the patient's clinical or physical condition?
Has the patient got a history of falls from the bed? Have they used bed rails before?
What are the patient's views on the use of bed rails?
What configuration of bed and mattress equipment is being used?
Potential harms can arise from:
rolling over the top of the rail
climbing over the rail
climbing over the footboard
violently shaking and dislodging rails
violent contact with bedrail parts

5.8.1 Investigations into adverse incidents involving bed rails have identified some patient characteristics which may increase the likelihood of injury/entrapment when bed rails are used. These include patients with:
Communication difficulties
Confusion, agitation or delirium
Learning disabilities
Very high or low body mass (which may increase the risk of entrapment)
Atypical body morphology e.g. extremes of height, weight or amputation
Impaired bed mobility
5.8.2 Patients with these conditions may require additional consideration but they should not be used as exclusion criteria in and of themselves.

5.8.3 Decisions regarding the use of Bed Rails are a balance of competing risks. In addition the patient's condition may be dynamic and decisions may need review at any time. Decisions are taken on clinical judgement and it is acknowledged that patients' presentations and behaviours may change and are not always predictable.
Bed rail “Bumpers”

5.9.1 Bed rail bumpers may be added to the rails to reduce the likelihood of impact injuries or skin tears. Bed rail bumpers are not usually adjustable and must be matched to the bed and bed rails on which they are to be used. Bed bumpers must be used as recommended by the manufacturer.
5.9.2 Bed bumpers which are compressible may increase entrapment risk.
5.9.3 When using bed bumpers consideration should be given to the fact that they reduce the patient's ability to see out from the bed and may therefore may cause distress.
Incident reporting:
5.10.1  Adverse events arising from bed rails must be incident reported in line with the MSEPO-19015 Procedure Report Management of Incidents and Serious Incidents
Supply, cleaning and maintenance
Wherever possible integral rails should be used in preference to “third party” or removable rails
Adequate supply of beds will be provided via MEMS
Bed rail bumpers are currently supplied, maintained and stored by the Ward areas where they are used
Training Requirements
The Moving and Handling team will provide training on the physical use of bed rails

There are no specific training requirements for the decision to use bed rails as this is based on clinical judgement and knowledge of the individual patients' characteristics and requirements. In cases where the decision maker is unsure they should discuss with a senior member of staff or seek advice from the Moving and Handling team or In-Patient Falls Teams.
Monitoring and Audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the DoN and DDoN meeting group members, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local DoN and DDoN meeting group documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the DoN and DDoN meeting group members of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
